description: From a dialect word meaning "blow in gusts".

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, slang) An overcomplicated task, especially one perceived as a waste of time.
examples: Adjusting this television is a bit of a faff.

entries.meaning: (typically in the phrase 'in a faff') A state of confused or frantic activity.
examples: She's in a total faff about tonight's dinner party.

verbs.description: faff (third-person singular simple present faffs, present participle faffing, simple past and past participle faffed)

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand) To waste time on an unproductive activity.
